Award.AwardTitle: Nitronate monooxygenase: A model for flavosemiquinones in oxidative catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Giovanni Gadda from Georgia State University to elucidate the enzymology of nitronate monooxygenase, a flavin-dependent enzyme that oxidizes propionate 3-nitronate to malonic semialdehyde, nitrite and nitrate. Oxidative catalysis, speeding up reactions that involve the transfer of electrons, is fundamental to life as it is at the core of the processes involved in the extraction of useful energy from fuel, such as carbohydrates and fats. Organisms then use the extracted energy to do work, to move, and to make the various molecules of life. The involvement of flavosemiquinones in oxidative catalysis has not been studied until now. This research project focuses on nitronate monooxygenase, flavosemiquinone-dependent enzyme. This pursuit will foster the integration of experiments with the education and training of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students in a variety of techniques in a multidisciplinary research environment. This will equip future generations of scientists with tools that are in high demand to fill the gap that exists between a wealth of information at the genome level and knowledge at the protein structure and function level. Educational and outreach activities beyond the laboratory will include the annual Southeast Enzyme Conference in Atlanta, the Chemistry Graduate Program and the Annual Chemistry Department Poster Day at Georgia State University.

This project will provide an opportunity to investigate the oxidation of catalytically relevant flavosemiquinones in the active sites of enzymes. The involvement of flavosemiquinones in oxidative catalysis has not been studied until now. This research project will investigate the properties of nitronate monooxygenase, an enzyme that uses flavosemiquinones in catalysis. The experimental approaches will combine steady-state and rapid kinetics, pH effects, mutagenesis and crystallography. The results will contribute to an understanding of the enzymology of nitronate monooxygenase and the reactivity of flavosemiquinones with oxygen in the active sites of enzymes. The project will also elucidate the chemical mechanism of catalysis for a member of Class H of the flavin-dependent monooxygenases, an enzymatic class that uses flavosemiquinones instead of using C4a-hydroperoxy-flavin intermediates.

Institution.Name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxidative catalysis is fundamental to life processes because it extracts useful energy from carbohydrate and fat fuels. The energy is then used by organisms across all kingdoms for work, motion, biosynthesis, detoxification, signal transduction, and other processes. Due to their versatility, flavoproteins play fundamental roles in oxidative catalysis. However, the involvement of the one electron reduced state of flavin cofactors, known as flavosemiquinone, in oxidative catalysis has been under-appreciated thus far. This project has investigated at a molecular level the biochemical and structural properties of nitronate monooxygenase, a bacterial and fungal flavin-dependent enzyme involved in oxidative catalysis that uses flavosemiquinones as catalytic intermediates of reaction. Four major outcomes have emerged in the project. First, the importance of the positive charge on the conserved active site residue H183 in the mechanism for oxygen incorporation in the product of the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme was established through mutagenesis, mechanistic, and structural studies. Second, we established that the geometry and spatial arrangement of the reactive centers in the enzyme-substrate complex to allow flavin reduction to the semiquinone state is less critical than in other flavin-dependent monooxygenases operating through hydride transfer mechanisms. Third, the structure of fungal nitronate monooxygenase was solved through X-ray crystallography, allowing for a direct comparison of the active site residues present in eukaryotic and prokaryotic nitronate monooxygenases. Fourth, the functional annotation of more than 5,000 genes previously mis-annotated as nitronate monooxygenase was corrected through biochemical and structural studies, establishing three classes of enzymes that include nitronate monooxygenase, NADH:quinone reductase, and NAD(P)H:quinone reductase. The scientific outcomes have provided detailed mechanistic and structural insights into nitronate monooxygenase, establishing the enzyme as a paradigm for Class H flavin-dependent monooxygenases. 

The scientific outcomes of this research project have been published in 25 peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals. One high school student, one undergraduate student, 20 graduate students, and 8 postdoctoral associates, have authored and co-authored the publications. The PI presented 4 invited talks, and his students presented 15 talks and >50 poster presentations. Three students graduated with Ph.D. degrees, three students with a Master of Science degree, and two students with an Undergraduate Honors Thesis. Several of the undergraduate students associated with the project have graduated and furthered their education, enrolling in graduate programs. Students in the PI's group have also actively contributed to the success of the Annual Southeast Enzyme Conference, which has been organized by the PI in Atlanta since 2010, by working with the PI on the organization of the conference, thus gaining skills and knowledge on this important outreach activity.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2019
Modified by: Giovanni Gadda
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Oxidative catalysis is fundamental to life processes because it extracts useful energy from carbohydrate and fat fuels. The energy is then used by organisms across all kingdoms for work, motion, biosynthesis, detoxification, signal transduction, and other processes. Due to their versatility, flavoproteins play fundamental roles in oxidative catalysis. However, the involvement of the one electron reduced state of flavin cofactors, known as flavosemiquinone, in oxidative catalysis has been under-appreciated thus far. This project has investigated at a molecular level the biochemical and structural properties of nitronate monooxygenase, a bacterial and fungal flavin-dependent enzyme involved in oxidative catalysis that uses flavosemiquinones as catalytic intermediates of reaction. Four major outcomes have emerged in the project. First, the importance of the positive charge on the conserved active site residue H183 in the mechanism for oxygen incorporation in the product of the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme was established through mutagenesis, mechanistic, and structural studies. Second, we established that the geometry and spatial arrangement of the reactive centers in the enzyme-substrate complex to allow flavin reduction to the semiquinone state is less critical than in other flavin-dependent monooxygenases operating through hydride transfer mechanisms. Third, the structure of fungal nitronate monooxygenase was solved through X-ray crystallography, allowing for a direct comparison of the active site residues present in eukaryotic and prokaryotic nitronate monooxygenases. The scientific outcomes have provided detailed mechanistic and structural insights into nitronate monooxygenase, establishing the enzyme as a paradigm for Class H flavin-dependent monooxygenases. The scientific outcomes of this research project have been published in 25 peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals. One high school student, one undergraduate student, 20 graduate students, and 8 postdoctoral associates, have authored and co-authored the publications. The PI presented 4 invited talks, and his students presented 15 talks and >50 poster presentations. Three students graduated with Ph.D. degrees, three students with a Master of Science degree, and two students with an Undergraduate Honors Thesis. Several of the undergraduate students associated with the project have graduated and furthered their education, enrolling in graduate programs.
